instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the analysis of black pepper samples?
Output: The analysis of black pepper samples used two types of spectra: visible-near infrared (VIS/NIR) spectra and mass spectrometric spectra obtained from direct analysis in real time-mass spectrometer (DART-MS).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the detection of adulterants in black pepper?
Output: Spectroscopic techniques such as ATR-FTIR and DART-MS were used in the detection of adulterants in black pepper.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning models in detecting adulterants in black pepper, and how far can this metric go in terms of correct classification?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning models in detecting adulterants in black pepper was the correct classification rate. This metric measures the percentage of samples that were correctly classified by the models. According to the text, the performance of the models, when evaluated using this metric, was typically greater than 75% correct classification.

instruction: What was the overall objective of using machine learning models in the analysis of black pepper samples for detecting adulterants?
Output: The overall objective of using machine learning models in the analysis of black pepper samples for detecting adulterants was to develop a methodology that could detect any addition without prior knowledge of the type of adulterant. instruction: Can the high-level fusion modeling using a penalized excess scoring system be considered a superior approach compared to traditional methods in detecting any type of adulterant in black pepper without prior knowledge of the specific adulterant?
Output: Yes, the high-level fusion modeling using a penalized excess scoring system can be considered a superior approach compared to traditional methods in detecting any type of adulterant in black pepper without prior knowledge of the specific adulterant. The study mentioned in the text showed that this approach led to a performance of typically >75% correct classification, regardless of the nature of the adulterant.
